{{Infobox organization | logo = International_Center_for_Biosaline_Agriculture_Logo.png | logo_alt = International Center for Biosaline Agriculture Logo | motto = Agriculture for tomorrow | type = International, non-profit | headquarters = Dubai, United Arab Emirates | leader_title = Director General | leader_name = Ismahane Elouafi | leader_title2 = Chair of Board of Directors | leader_name2 = Abdulrahman Sultan Alsharhan | parent_organization = | founded = 1999 | website = http://www.biosaline.org/ | region_served = Central Asia and the Caucasus, the Middle East and North Africa, South and South East Asia, sub-Saharan Africa and the Gulf Cooperation Council | abbreviation = ICBA }}'''ICBA''' (International Center for Biosaline Agriculture) is an international, non-profit agricultural research and development center which focuses on the closely linked issues of water, environment, income, and [[food security]]. ICBA conducts research and development programs that aim to improve agricultural productivity and sustainability in marginal environments.
Its headquarters are in [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] and it is a founding member of the [[Association of International Research and Development Centers for Agriculture]] (AIRCA).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.airca.org/index.php/airca-members|title=AIRCA Members|website=www.airca.org|access-date=2016-04-02}}</ref> It is also a member of Middle East and North Africa Network of Water Centers of Excellence<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://menanwc.org/about-network/current-members/international-center-biosaline-agriculture-icba|title=International Center for Biosaline Agriculture (ICBA)|website=Middle East and North Africa Network of Water Centers of Excellence|access-date=2016-04-02}}</ref> and the Asia-Pacific Association of Agricultural Research Institutions (APAARI).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apaari.org/about/members/|title=Members : APAARI|website=Asia Pacific Association of Agricultural Research Institutions|access-date=2016-04-17}}</ref>
== History ==
In 1992, the [[Islamic Development Bank]] (IDB) initiated a series of expert consultations which outlined the objectives and activities of the new institute. In November 1992, the IDB Board of Executive Directors approved financing for start-up operations. Subsequent consultations between the Bank and the General Secretariat of the [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] led to the selection of the United Arab Emirates as a host country for the new center.
In 1996, the IDB and the Government of the UAE signed an agreement to establish ICBA as a formal entity. In 1997, the Municipality of Dubai donated 100 hectares of land at Al Ruwayyah, where ICBA's head office is now based. The center became operational in 1999.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783319057675|title=Environmental Cost and Face of Agriculture in the Gulf Cooperation Council Countries|last=Shahid|first=Shabbir A.|last2=Ahmed|first2=Mushtaque|publisher=Springer International Publishing|year=2014|isbn=978-3-319-05768-2|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Funding == [[File:International_Center_for_Biosaline_Agriculture_Headquarters.jpg|alt=International Center for Biosaline Agriculture Headquarters in Dubai, United Arab Emirates|thumb|618x618px|International Center for Biosaline Agriculture Headquarters at Al Ruwayyah in Dubai, United Arab Emirates|none]] ICBA’s founding donors were the Islamic Development Bank (IDB), the [[OPEC Fund for International Development]] (OFID), the [[Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development]] (AFESD), and the [[Politics of the United Arab Emirates|Government of the United Arab Emirates]] (UAE).
Currently the Center is funded by the three core donors: the Ministry of Climate Change and Environment of the UAE (formerly the Ministry of Environment and Water); the Environment Agency - Abu Dhabi; and the Islamic Development Bank. The Center has additional support from several development agencies and international donors such as the [[International Fund for Agricultural Development]] (IFAD), the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA), the UAE Government, Dubai and Abu Dhabi Municipalities, and the private sector in Oman and Saudi Arabia.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470290187.ch16/summary|title=The Role of Biosaline Agriculture in Managing Freshwater Shortages and Improving Water Security|last=Al-Attar|first=Mohammad|date=2003|publisher=Iowa State Press|isbn=9780470290187|editor-last=Scanes|editor-first=Colin G.|pages=271–280|language=en|doi=10.1002/9780470290187.ch16|editor-last2=Miranowski|editor-first2=John A.}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Inayatullah|first=Sohail|last2=Elouafi|first2=Ismahane A.|date=2014|title=The alternative futures of the International Centre for Biosaline Agriculture: from salinity research to greening the desert|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/FS-08-2013-0030|journal=Foresight|volume=16|issue=5|pages=389–409|doi=10.1108/FS-08-2013-0030|issn=1463-6689}}</ref>
== Research and development focus == [[file:Ismahane Elouafi (cropped).jpg|thumb|Dr Ismahane Elouafiis the center's director (2015)]] Initially ICBA focused solely on biosaline environments but its applied research for development now aims to address agricultural challenges in all marginal environments.<ref name=":1" /> Its tasks include assessment of natural resources, [[Adaptation to global warming|climate change adaptation]], [[Agricultural productivity|crop productivity]] and diversification, [[aquaculture]], [[bioenergy]] and policy analysis.
ICBA works on a number of technological developments, including the use of conventional and non-conventional water (such as saline, [[Wastewater|treated wastewater]], [[Industrial water treatment|industrial water]], [[agricultural drainage]], and seawater);<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.zawya.com/story/Scientists_finding_ways_to_help_farmers_maximise_ground_water-GN_29032015_300309/|title=Scientists finding ways to help farmers maximise ground water|last=Ponce de Leon|first=Janice|date=29 March 2015|website=Thomson Reuters ZAWYA|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://muslim-science.com/icba-oasis-desert/|title=ICBA – An Oasis in the Desert|date=2 August 2014|website=Muslim Science|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref> water and land management technologies; and [[remote sensing]] and modeling for climate change adaptation.<ref name=":0" />
The Center conducts research on a variety of food crops which hold promise of being resilient, salt tolerant and water efficient. For example, ICBA has been conducting widespread research on [[quinoa]], a multi-purpose, high-protein grain crop which is drought and salt tolerant. ICBA initiated research on a number of quinoa germplasm accessions since 2006–07. The selections from these trials are being introduced to farmers in several countries, e.g. in the United Arab Emirates in Abu Dhabi.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://raconteur.net/sustainability/more-meat-eaters-means-uk-farmers-can-cash-in|title=UK farming addresses global meat demand|last=Wale|first=Michael|date=29 July 2015|website=Raconteur|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://icbawebsiteyn6lbe9b4h.devcloud.acquia-sites.com/sites/default/files/GulfTimes_quinoa_19072015.pdf|title=Proper value chain needed for Quinoa|last=Banerjee|first=Thirtho|date=19 July 2015|work=The Gulf Time|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
ICBA scientists are also working to increase the salinity tolerance of hardier traditional crops such as [[date palm]]s, [[sorghum]] and [[millet]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ozy.com/fast-forward/saltwater-saviors/30923|title=Saltwater Saviours|last=Cadei|first=Emily|date=15 April 2014|website=OZY|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref>
Another field of research lies with ''[[Salicornia]]'' and other [[halophyte]]s (salt-loving plants) that remove salts from saline soils and water.<ref name=":2" /> ''Salicornia’s'' oil-bearing seeds produce biofuel, cosmetic oil and edible vegetable oil. Its straws can also be used as animal fodder, and its vegetable tips can be harvested for human consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://technologyreview.me/en/materials/salicornia-biofuel/|title=Why research won’t give up on Salicornia|last=Hashem|first=Heba|date=25 March 2015|website=MIT Technology Review|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414091919/http://technologyreview.me/en/materials/salicornia-biofuel/|archivedate=14 April 2016|df=}}</ref> <gallery mode=packed heights=150px> File:Treated wastewater Jordan.jpg|Using treated wastewater for agriculture in Jordan - part of ICBA’s regional program File:Salicornia reseach plots at ICBA.JPG|''Salicornia'' research plots at International Center for Biosaline Agriculture File:Salicornia trials at International Center for Biosaline Agriculture.jpg|Salt-tolerant ''Salicornia'' shows promise for bioenergy. File:Quinoa Chenopodium quinoa.jpg|ICBA has been evaluating quinoa for use in dry and saline environments. </gallery>
== Reach == The geographic scope of ICBA has grown since its inception. It now focusses its work on water-scarce countries of the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) including Gulf Cooperation Council countries (GCC), Central Asia and the Caucasus (CAC) and South and Southwest Asia. It is currently expanding to include countries of sub-Saharan Africa (SSA).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-94-007-0519-7_3|title=Turning Adversity into an Advantage for Food Security Through Improving Soil Quality and Providing Production Systems for Marginal Saline Lands: ICBA Perspectives and Approach|last=Shahid|first=Shabbir A.|last2=Taha|first2=Faisal K.|last3=Ismail|first3=Shoaib|last4=Dakheel|first4=Abdullah|last5=Abdelfattah|first5=Mahmoud|date=2011|publisher=Springer Netherlands|isbn=9789400705180|editor-last=Behnassi|editor-first=Mohamed|pages=43–67|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-94-007-0519-7_3|editor-last2=Shahid|editor-first2=Shabbir A.|editor-last3=D'Silva|editor-first3=Joyce}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Biosalinity]] * [[Halophyte]] * [[Quinoa]] * [[Salicornia]] * [[Brackish water]]

'''Julia Bryan-Wilson''' is a Professor in the Department of [[History of art|History of Art]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref name="berkeley1">{{cite web|url=http://arthistory.berkeley.edu/person/1639580-julia-bryan-wilson|title=Julia Bryan-Wilson Professor - UC Berkeley History of Art Department|last=|first=|date=2000-01-25|website=|publisher=Arthistory.berkeley.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2014-02-01}}</ref>
== Career == Bryan-Wilson received her B.A. from [[Swarthmore College]] in 1995 and her Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley in 2004. In addition to teaching at the University of California, Berkeley, Bryan-Wilson has also taught at the [[Rhode Island School of Design]], [[California College of the Arts]], the [[University of California, Irvine]], and at the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]], London. She also served as one of the Robert Sterling Clark Professors in the Graduate Art History department at [[Williams College]] from 2018-2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gradart.williams.edu/julia-bryan-wilson-and-mel-chen-to-serve-jointly-as-robert-sterling-clark-professors-for-2018-2019/|title=Julia Bryan-Wilson and Mel Chen to serve jointly as Robert Sterling Clark Professors for 2018-2019 {{!}} Grad Art|website=gradart.williams.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref>
Bryan-Wilson studies [[Feminist theory|feminist]] and [[queer theory]], modern and contemporary art, craft histories, and questions of artistic labor, as well as [[photography]], [[Videography|video]], collaborative practices, and [[visual culture]] of the [[Atomic Age]].<ref name="berkeley1" />
Her book, ''Art Workers: Radical Practice in the Vietnam War Era,'' was published by the [[University of California Press]] in 2009.<ref name="Ucpress.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/books/pages/10899.php|title=Art Workers - Julia Bryan-Wilson - Paperback - University of California Press|date=|publisher=Ucpress.edu|accessdate=2014-02-01}}</ref> Her second book, ''Fray: Art and Textile Politics'', was published by the [[University of Chicago Press]] in 2017<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/F/bo11040813.html|title=Fray}}</ref> and was awarded the 2018 [[Robert Motherwell]] Book Award by the Dedalus Foundation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://update.lib.berkeley.edu/2018/06/12/professor-julia-bryan-wilson-receives-the-2018-robert-motherwell-book-award/|title=Professor Julia Bryan-Wilson receives the 2018 Robert Motherwell Book Award|date=2018-06-12|work=UC Berkeley Library Update|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en-US}}</ref> ''Fray'' was also awarded the Book Prize from The Association for the Study of the Arts of the Present (or ASAP).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artsofthepresent.org/2018/11/15/announcing-the-asap-book-prize-winner/|title=Announcing the ASAP Book Prize Winner|last=|first=|date=|website=www.artsofthepresent.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-25}}</ref> Bryan-Wilson's article, "Invisible Products," published in the Summer 2012 issue of ''[[Art Journal (College Art Association journal)|Art Journal]]'', received the 2013 Art Journal Award for Outstanding Article of the Year from the [[College Art Association]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://artjournal.collegeart.org/?page_id=73|title=Art Journal Award - Art Journal Open|work=Art Journal Open|access-date=2018-10-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
She is the editor of ''Robert Morris (October Files),''<ref>https://mitpress.mit.edu/books/robert-morris</ref> published by the [[MIT Press|Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in 2013. With [[Glenn Adamson]], Byran-Wilson is also the co-author of ''Art in the Making: Artists and their Materials from the Studio to Crowdsourcing (1st Edition)'',<ref>http://www.thamesandhudsonusa.com/books/art-in-the-making-artists-and-their-materials-from-the-studio-to-crowdsourcing-hardcover</ref> published by [[Thames & Hudson]] in June 2016.
Bryan-Wilson is co-curator of ''Cecilia Vicuña: About to Happen''<ref>http://cacno.org/exhibitions/abouttohappen</ref> at the [[Contemporary Arts Center (New Orleans)|Contemporary Arts Center]] in New Orleans in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cacno.org/exhibitions/abouttohappen|title=Cecilia Vicuña: About to Happen {{!}} Contemporary Arts Center New Orleans|website=cacno.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-01}}</ref> The show traveled to the [[Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia|Institute for Contemporary Art]] at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in February 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://icaphila.org/exhibitions/cecilia-vicuna-about-to-happen/|title=Cecilia Vicuña: About to Happen - ICA Philadelphia|website=icaphila.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Michael Oppenheimer | image = Michael Oppenheimer, PhD.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = Michael Oppenheimer, PhD | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|02|28}} | birth_place = New York City | nationality = American | education = S.B. ([[M.I.T.]]) in Chemistry; Ph.D. ([[University of Chicago]]) in [[Chemical Physics]] | employer = [[Princeton University]] | occupation = Professor of [[Geosciences]] and International Affairs | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | awards = | website = [https://www.princeton.edu/step/people/faculty/michael-oppenheimer/ Oppenheimer's homepage] }} '''Michael Oppenheimer''' (born February 28, 1946) is the Albert G. Milbank Professor of [[Geosciences]] and International Affairs in the [[Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs]] and the Department of Geosciences at [[Princeton University]]. He is the Director of the Program in Science,Technology and Environmental Policy (STEP) at the Woodrow Wilson School and Faculty Associate of the Atmospheric and Ocean Sciences Program, Princeton Environmental Institute, and the [[Princeton Institute for International and Regional Studies]].<ref name=About>{{cite web|url=https://www.princeton.edu/step/people/faculty/michael-oppenheimer/|title=Michael Oppenheimer|author=Princenton University|accessdate= 14 May 2015}}</ref>
Oppenheimer has taken a leading role in various environmental and science policy related activities, with regard to [[acid rain]], and contributed to the 1990 amendments to the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]]. With regard to climate change, he was a major author of the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]] and a lead author of the Fifth Assessment Report.
Oppenheimer is also a prominent public figure and has discussed the various aspects of global warming in the media. He has been a guest on many television and radio programs and talk shows, including ABC's ''[[This Week (ABC TV series)|This Week]]'', ''[[Nightline]]'', ''Alcove'', ''[[The News Hour]]'', ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'', ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]'', ''[[ABC News]]'' and ''[[The Colbert Report]]''. Oppenheimer is the author of over 140 articles published in professional journals.
He is the author of ''Dead Heat: The Race Against The Greenhouse Effect'', written together with environmental activist Robert H. Boyle and published in 1990. Oppenheimer is co-founder of the [[Climate Action Network]].
== Background == Oppenheimer (born February 28, 1946 in NYC) joined the Princeton faculty after more than two decades with The [[Environmental Defense Fund]] (EDF), a non-governmental, environmental organization, where he served as chief scientist and manager of the Climate and Air Program. Prior to his position at The Environmental Defense Fund, Dr. Oppenheimer served as Atomic and Molecular Astrophysicist at the [[Harvard–Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics]] and Lecturer on Astronomy at [[Harvard University]]. He received an S.B. in chemistry from [[M.I.T.]], a Ph.D. in chemical physics from the [[University of Chicago]], and pursued post-doctoral research at the Harvard–Smithsonian Center. He continues to serve as a science advisor to EDF. Oppenheimer has been a member of several panels of the [[National Academy of Sciences]] and is now a member of the National Academies' Board on Energy and Environmental Systems. He is also a winner of the 2010 [[Heinz Award]] with special focus on global change<ref name="The Heinz Awards">{{cite web|title=The Heinz Awards: Michael Oppenheimer|url=http://www.heinzawards.net/recipients/michael-oppenheimer|website=The Heinz Awards|publisher=The Heinz Awards|accessdate=August 26, 2016}}</ref> and a [[Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science]].<ref name=About />
== Research interests == His interests include science and policy of the atmosphere, particularly [[Effects of global warming|climate change and its impacts]]. Much of his research aims to understand the potential for "dangerous" outcomes of increasing levels of greenhouse gases by exploring the effects of global warming on ecosystems such as [[coral reefs]], on the [[ice sheets]] and [[sea level]], and on patterns of [[human migration]].<ref name=About /> He has assessed linkages among climate change, crop yields and Mexico–US cross-border migration.{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}} Oppenheimer studies the process of scientific learning and scientific assessments and their role in influencing public policies to respond to global change.{{Citation needed|date=May 2015}}
== Role in global science policy == Oppenheimer is a long-time participant in the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) which won the [[Nobel Peace Prize in 2007]], serving recently as a lead author of the [[IPCC's Fourth Assessment Report]] and then as a coordinating lead author of the [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report|Fifth Assessment Report]] as well as a Special Report on climate extremes and disasters. In the late 1980s, Dr. Oppenheimer and a handful of other scientists organized two workshops under the auspices of the [[United Nations]] that helped precipitate the negotiations that resulted in the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (signed at the [[1992 Earth Summit]]) and the [[Kyoto Protocol]]. During that period, he co-founded the [[Climate Action Network]]. His research and advocacy work on [[acid rain]] also contributed to the passage of the 1990 amendments to the [[Clean Air Act (United States)|Clean Air Act]].
=== Assessment of the IPCC process === In 2007, he wrote about limitations of the IPCC consensus approach in Science Magazine.<ref name=MO>{{cite journal | author = Oppenheimer Michael | year = 2007 | title = The limits of consensus", in ''Science Magazine's State of the Planet 2008-2009: with a Special Section on Energy and Sustainability'', Donald Kennedy, Island Press, 01.12.2008, separate as Michael Oppenheimer, Brian C. O'Neill, Mort Webster, Shardul Agrawal, "CLIMATE CHANGE, The Limits of Consensus | url = | journal = [[Science (magazine)|Science]] | volume = 317 | issue = 5844| pages = 1505–06 | doi = 10.1126/science.1144831 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> The current centralized assessment role of the IPCC allows for "communication in a monolithic message" but risks "ossification and eventual irrelevance" of the IPCC as an institution.<ref name=yo/> According to him, the ''problem of creating, defending and communicating consensus results as well as departures from the consensus'' had been discussed but not addressed until after the AR4.<ref name=yo/> Oppenheimer notes important recent major changes within the IPCC, including a stronger focus on uncertainty since the [[InterAcademy Panel]] IAC 2010 IPCC review and a focus upon risk management approaches based on fundamental conclusions in the AR4 Synthesis Report.<ref name=yo/> With regard to the IPCC double role as trying to communicate its results both to governments and to the general public, he sees the organization as not being entirely successful at either.<ref name=yo/> The IPCC needs, according to Oppenheimer et al., to decide whether it intends to communicate with the general public at all.<ref name=yo/>
In 2011, together with [[Gary Yohe]], he published an essay, with a scope on the uncertainties in the IPCC assessments regarding e.g. [[climate sensitivity]] and a potential collapse of the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet]], and about the similarly important evolution of socio-political-economic systems.<ref name=yo>{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/s10584-011-0176-8|journal=Climatic Change|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10584-011-0176-8/fulltext.html|title=Evaluation, characterization, and communication of uncertainty by the intergovernmental panel on climate change—an introductory essay|authors=Gary Yohe and Michael Oppenheimer|date=13 August 2011|volume=108|pages=629–639}}</ref>
Together with Jessica O'Reilly and [[Naomi Oreskes]], Oppenheimer discussed the case of the [[West Antarctic Ice Sheet]] assessment in IPCC reports in a [[Social Studies of Science]] paper 2012. The possible disastrous outcome of a disintegration of the WAIS for global sea levels was assessed in the [[IPCC Third Assessment Report]] but was barely addressed in the [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report]]. IPCC authors were less confident about predictions of WAIS disintegration not only due to new science results published since the Third Assessment, but also due to reasons of internal "culture", such as changes of IPCC chairpersons, authors teams, and chapter organization made which it too difficult to project the range of possible futures for the WAIS as desired by governments.<ref name=ore>The Rapid Disintegration of Projections: The West Antarctic Ice Sheet and the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Jessica O'Reilly, [[Naomi Oreskes]], Michael Oppenheimer Social Studies of Science June 26, 2012, {{DOI|10.1177/0306312712448130}}</ref>
== Recent awards and honors == * 2000: [[League of Conservation Voters]], Environmental Leadership Award * 2001: Environmental Action Coalition Green Star Award * 2005–2006: [[Russell Sage Foundation Visiting Scholar]] * 2007: New Species Award, [[African Rainforest Conservancy]] * 2009-2010: [[Russell Sage Foundation]] Associate Scholar * 2010–2013: [[National Science Foundation]] Grant: Assessing Assessments * 2010: Named as a [[AAAS Fellow]] * 2010: 16th Annual [[Heinz Award]] with special focus on global change<ref name="The Heinz Awards"/> * 2014 Linacre Lecturer,Oxford University
==Selected publications== Overview of publications at [https://scholar.google.de/citations?user=yZ8k3zMAAAAJ&hl=en Google Scholar].

Cycles | volume = 24 | issue = | page = 1001 | doi = 10.1029/2008GB003336 | bibcode=2010GBioC..24.1001G|display-authors=etal}} *{{cite journal | author = Feng A. Res. Lett. | volume = 4 | issue = | page = 2009 | doi = 10.1088/1748-9326/4/4/045106 | bibcode = 2009ERL.....4d5106M }} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Searchinger T, etal | year = 2009 | title = Fixing a critical climate accounting error | url = | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]] | volume = 326 | issue = | pages = 527–528 | doi = 10.1126/science.1178797 | pmid=19900885| bibcode = 2009Sci...326..527S}} *{{cite journal |author1=M. Oppenheimer |author2=BC O'Neill |author-link2=Brian C. O'Neill | author3=M. Webster | year = 2008 | title = Negative learning | url = | journal = [[Climatic Change]] | volume = 89 | issue = | pages = 155–172 | doi = 10.1007/s10584-008-9405-1 }} *{{cite journal | author = Donner | year = 2006 | title = Global Assessment of Coral Bleaching and Required Rates of Adaptation under Climate Change | url = | journal = Global Change Biology | volume = 11 | issue = | pages = 1–15 | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-2486.2005.01073.x |display-authors=etal| bibcode = 2005GCBio..11.2251D}} *{{cite journal | year = | title = Global warming and the stability of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet | url = http://kingreedbraden.googlepages.com/WAISandGlobalWarming.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Nature | volume = 393 | issue = | pages = 325–332 }} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Epstein CB, Oppenheimer M | year = 1986 | title = Empirical relation between sulphur dioxide emissions and acid deposition derived from monthly data | url = | journal = Nature | volume = 323 | issue = | pages = 245–7 | doi=10.1038/323245a0| bibcode = 1986Natur.323..245E}} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Hartquist TW, Dalgarno A, Oppenheimer M | year = 1980 | title = Molecular diagnostics of interstellar shocks | doi = 10.1086/157731 | journal = [[Astrophysical Journal]] | volume = 236 | issue = | page = 182 | bibcode = 1980ApJ...236..182H }} *{{cite journal |vauthors=Oppenheimer M, Dalgarno A | year = 1974 | title = The Fractional Ionization in Dense Interstellar Clouds | url = | journal = Astrophysical Journal | volume = 192 | issue = 1| pages = 29–32 | doi=10.1086/153030 | bibcode=1974ApJ...192...29O}}

'''Multimedia Studies''' is an interdisciplinary field of academic discourse focused on the understanding of technologies and cultural dimensions of linking traditional media sources with ones based on new media to support social systems.
==History== Multimedia Studies as a discipline came out of the need for media studies to be made relevant to the new world of CD-ROMs and [[hypertext]] in the 1990s. Revolutionary books like Jakob Nielsen's 'Hypertext and Hypermedia' book lay the foundations for understanding multimedia alongside traditional cognitive science and interface design issues.<ref>Nielsen, J. (1990). Hypertext and Hypermedia. Saunders College Publishing/Harcourt Brace. {{ISBN|0125184107}}</ref> Software like [[Adobe Authorware|Authorware Attain]], now owned by [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], made the design of multimedia systems accessible to those unskilled in programming and became major applications by the end of the 1990s<ref>Schifman, R.S. (1999). The Ultimate Authorware Tutorial. Springer-Verlag. {{ISBN|3540641238}}</ref>
===Recent Challenges=== The Internet age that has been growing since the launch of [[Windows 98]] has brought new challenges for the discipline including developing new models and rules for the World Wide Web. Areas such as usability have had to develop specific guidelines for Website design<ref>Nielsen, J. & Tahir, M. (2001). Homepage Usability: 50 Websites Deconstructed. {{ISBN|073571102X}}</ref> and traditional concepts like genre, narrative theory, and stereotypes have had to be updated to take account of Cyberculture.<ref>Herring, S.C., Scheidt, L.A. ; Bonus, S. ; Wright, E. (2004). Bridging the gap: a genre analysis of Weblogs. In: Proceedings of the 37th Annual Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences, 2004.</ref><ref>Robinson, K.M. (2001). Unsolicited Narratives from the Internet: A Rich Source of Qualitative Data. Qual Health Res 11 (5), 706-714</ref> Cultural aspects of Multimedia Studies have been conceptualised by authors such as [[Lev Manovich]],<ref name="Manovich 2003">{{cite book |last= Manovich |first= Lev |authorlink= Lev Manovich |editor= Noah Wardrip-Fruin, Nick Montfort |title= The New Media Reader |format= PDF |accessdate= 6 May 2007 |year= 2003 |publisher= [[MIT Press]] |pages= 13–25 |chapter= New Media from Borges to HTML |chapterurl= http://mrl.nyu.edu/~noah/nmr/book_samples/nmr-intro-manovich-excerpt.pdf |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061210054445/http://www.mrl.nyu.edu/~noah/nmr/book_samples/nmr-intro-manovich-excerpt.pdf |archivedate= 10 December 2006 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Manovich 2001">{{cite book |last= Manovich |first= Lev | authorlink= Lev Manovich |title= The Language of a New Media |publisher= [[MIT Press]] |year= 2001 |isbn= 0-262-63255-1}}</ref> [[Arturo Escobar (anthropologist)|Arturo Escobar]] and [[Fred Forest]].<ref name="Macek 2005">{{cite paper| author = Forest, Fred| title = Pour un art actuel, l'art à l'heure d'Internet | date = | url = http://www.fredforest.org/artactuel/index.html }}</ref>
The increase in [[Troll (Internet)|Internet trolling]] and so-called [[Internet addiction]] has thrown up new problems. Concepts like emotional design <ref>Norman, D.A. (2005). Emotional Design: Why We Love (or Hate) Everyday Things. Basic Books.</ref> and affective computing <ref>Picard, R. (2000). Affective Computing. MIT Press. {{ISBN|0262661152}}</ref> are driving Multimedia Studies research to consider ways of becoming more seductive and able to take account of the different needs of users.
====Media Studies 2.0==== Some academics, such as [[David Gauntlett]], have preferred the neologism, 'Media Studies 2.0' to Multimedia Studies, in order to give it the feel of other fields like [[Web 2.0]] and Classroom 2.0.<ref name="BFI">British Film Institute, [http://www.bfi.org.uk/education/conferences/mediastudies2007/ Media Studies Conference 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107113722/http://www.bfi.org.uk/education/conferences/mediastudies2007/ |date=2007-11-07 }}, 4–6 July 2007</ref><ref name="TA">[http://www.transformingaudiences.org.uk Transforming Audiences International Conference], 6–7 September 2007</ref><ref name="AR2">Andy Ruddock (2008), [http://www.blackwell-synergy.com/doi/pdf/10.1111/j.1751-9020.2007.00040.x 'Media Studies 2.0? Binge Drinking and Why Audiences Still Matter'], ''Sociology Compass'', Volume 2 Issue 1 Page 1-15, January 2008.</ref><ref name="GL">[http://www.rickinstrell.co.uk/GeoffLealand.ppt 'Towards a Brave New World? The Media Studies 2.0 Debate'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003185242/http://www.rickinstrell.co.uk/GeoffLealand.ppt |date=2011-10-03 }}, presentation by Geoff Lealand, University of Waikato, at AMES conference, May 2007</ref><ref name="WM">[http://twopointzeroforum.blogspot.com/ Blog/forum about Media Studies 2.0] by William Merrin</ref> The Media Studies 2.0 neologism has received strong criticism. Andy Medhurst at Sussex University for instance wrote of the Media Studies 2.0 neologism introduced by David Gauntlett, 'Isn't it odd that whenever someone purportedly identifies a new paradigm, they see themselves as already a leading practitioner of it?'
